<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 393, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 275, 450]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 450, 760, 466]]<|/det|>
Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 466, 806, 482]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 482, 562, 497]]<|/det|>
Write your answer to each question in the space provided.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 498, 480, 512]]<|/det|>
Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 513, 361, 527]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 528, 866, 559]]<|/det|>
If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 560, 480, 575]]<|/det|>
You should use a calculator where appropriate.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 575, 880, 605]]<|/det|>
You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 606, 856, 636]]<|/det|>
Give non- exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 665, 220, 680]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 682, 384, 697]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 50.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 698, 728, 713]]<|/det|>
The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
A basketball club has a large number of players. The heights, \(x \mathrm{m}\), of a random sample of 10 of these players are measured. A \(90\%\) confidence interval for the population mean height, \(\mu \mathrm{m}\), of players in this club is calculated. It is assumed that heights are normally distributed. The confidence interval is \(1.78 \leqslant \mu \leqslant 2.02\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 490, 168]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(\Sigma x\) and \(\Sigma x^2\) for this sample.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 149, 920, 168]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 92, 88]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 920, 135]]<|/det|> In the colleges in three regions of a particular country, students are given individual targets to achieve. Their performance is measured against their individual target and graded as ‘above target’, ‘on target’ or ‘below target’. For a random sample of students from each of the three regions, the observed frequencies are summarised in the following table. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 141, 920, 295]]<|/det|>
RegionTotal
ABC
PerformanceAbove target624144147
On target1029495291
Below target564561162
Total220180200600
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 312, 761, 331]]<|/det|> Test, at the \(10\%\) significance level, whether performance is independent of region. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 312, 920, 331]]<|/det|> [7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 96, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
A scientist is investigating the masses of birds of a certain species in country \(X\) and country \(Y.\) She takes a random sample of 50 birds of this species from country \(X\) and a random sample of 80 birds of this species from country \(Y.\) She records their masses in \(\mathrm{kg}, x\) and \(y,\) respectively. Her results are summarised as follows.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[235, 147, 801, 168]]<|/det|>
\[\Sigma x = 75.5\qquad \Sigma x^2 = 115.2\qquad \Sigma y = 116.8\qquad \Sigma y^2 = 172.6\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 179, 880, 199]]<|/det|>
The population mean masses of these birds in countries \(X\) and \(Y\) are \(\mu_{x}\mathrm{kg}\) and \(\mu_{y}\mathrm{kg}\) respectively.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 210, 920, 246]]<|/det|>
Test, at the \(5\%\) significance level, the null hypothesis \(\mu_{x} = \mu_{y}\) against the alternative hypothesis \(\mu_{x} > \mu_{y}\). State your conclusion in the context of the question.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 229, 917, 247]]<|/det|>
<mark>[8]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 92, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 724, 91]]<|/det|>
The continuous random variable \(X\) has probability density function f given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[359, 97, 638, 155]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}(x) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll}k & 0\leqslant x< 1,\\ kx & 1\leqslant x\leqslant 2,\\ 0 & \mathrm{otherwise}, \end{array} \right.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 163, 288, 181]]<|/det|>
where \(k\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 194, 144, 212]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 194, 292, 212]]<|/det|>
Show that \(k = \frac{2}{5}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 196, 918, 214]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 444, 185, 463]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 444, 415, 463]]<|/det|>
Find the interquartile range of \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 444, 920, 463]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 96, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
A 6-sided dice, \(A\), with faces numbered 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 is biased so that the probability of throwing a 6 is \(\frac{1}{4}\). The random variable \(X\) is the number of 6s obtained when dice \(A\) is thrown twice.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 121, 144, 140]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 121, 512, 140]]<|/det|>
Find the probability generating function of \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 121, 920, 140]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 432, 920, 467]]<|/det|>
A second dice, \(B\), with faces numbered 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6 is unbiased. The random variable \(Y\) is the number of 6s obtained when dice \(B\) is thrown twice.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 478, 826, 497]]<|/det|>
The random variable \(Z\) is the total number of 6s obtained when both dice are thrown twice.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 509, 144, 528]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 509, 831, 528]]<|/det|>
Find the probability generating function of \(Z\), expressing your answer as a polynomial.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 509, 920, 528]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 262, 91]]<|/det|>
Find \(\text{Var}(Z)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 918, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 656, 186, 675]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 656, 789, 675]]<|/det|>
Use the probability generating function of \(Z\) to find the most probable value of \(Z\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 658, 918, 677]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
The manager of a technology company \(A\) claims that his employees earn more per year than the employees at technology company \(B\). The amounts earned per year, in hundreds of dollars, by a random sample of 12 employees from company \(A\) and an independent random sample of 12 employees from company \(B\) are shown below.

<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 171, 920, 203]]<|/det|>
Carry out a Wilcoxon rank-sum test at the \(5\%\) significance level to test whether the manager's claim is supported by the data.
